globalMetadata.title: Good Thinking - NHS approved wellbeing service
globalMetadata.description: Anxious, stressed, depressed or having trouble sleeping? Find NHS-approved mental health tools and advice to support you.

attributes.alternativeText: Group of friends sitting on grass in front of London skyline
attributes.name: OG Image.png

links.text: Find the right help for you

footer.description: Good Thinking provides a range of resources to help Londoners improve their mental wellbeing.

subscribeFooterText.copy: Get the latest tips and resources for Londoners delivered to your inbox every month.

partners.name: Transformation Partners in Health and Care

howToUseSection.bodyText:
Find support, advice and resources by:

  • Mental health concern

Sleep, Anxiety, Low mood, Stress.

  • Audience

Young people, Employers and employees, Someone who is grieving, Faith and belief communities.

  • Type of support

Self-assessments, free apps, podcasts, videos, how to guides, workbooks.

Get expert advice from Good Thinking

The Good Thinking team has created a broad range of advice in collaboration with clinical and subject-area experts, designed to support Londoners with everyday mental health challenges.

In our Latest Advice section, you'll find short guides with tips and resource recommendations to help you with a range of concerns including dealing with uncertainty, money worries, getting enough sleep and coping with bereavement. 

If you’re looking for advice on a specific subject, type in your topic in the ‘search﻿’ box at the top of the page.

howToUseSection.bodyText:
Use the Good Thinking self-assessment tool

Our in-depth, clinically validated self-assessments are a thorough assessment of both your mental and physical wellbeing. They may seem quite ‘medical’ because they are based on the types of questions a doctor or a psychologist might ask you.

  • Each self-assessment takes around 20 minutes to complete
  • Answer questions about yourself or someone you may be concerned about
  • You’ll get a personalised list of recommended actions to take forward

howToUseSection.bodyText:
Find the right help for you

Tell us what you're looking for help with and who you're looking for help for and you’ll then receive personalised recommendations for apps and other resources to meet your needs.

blogData.title: What makes you happy?
blogData.subtitle: A guest blog by the Black Students Mental Health Project at London South Bank University (LSBU). This blog asks ‘do you know what brings happiness to your life?’ and helps you to focus on the small things that bring you joy as a pathway to boosting your mental wellbeing.

metadata.description: A guest blog by the Black Students Mental Health Project at London South Bank University.
metadata.title: What makes you happy?

attributes.alternativeText: Title graphic for the OfS Black Students Mental Health Project. The title of the project is written above a graphic of a group of black students. The OfS, LSBU and Good Thinking logos are displayed

large.name: large_094-2122-SJ-COM-Black student mental health web graphic2.jpg

small.name: small_094-2122-SJ-COM-Black student mental health web graphic2.jpg

author.name: Cheryl Taylor
author.title: LSBU Integrated Wellbeing Advisor and OfS Black Students Mental Health Project Officer

attributes.alternativeText: Headshot of Cheryl Taylor, LSBU Black Students Mental Health Project Officer
attributes.name: LSBU_Cheryl_003.JPG

contentSections.content:
Sometimes, the mental health field can seem to focus solely on the things we want to move away from rather than on what we want to move towards. Blogs and posts cover topics such as coping with depression or anxiety and exploring what you can do about trauma. 

Whilst these things are important, we can sometimes miss the wood for the trees. In this example, the trees are the occasions in our life and the wood is a life well lived. To have a life well lived, we need not only focus on the things that go wrong but, more importantly, look for those things that go right and bring joy and happiness into our lives. 

Take a moment to reflect

The question is, do you know what brings happiness to your life? When was the last time you caught yourself being happy? Where were you? What were you doing? Who were you doing it with? 

Spend a few moments right now thinking about where you were when you last felt happy, who you were with and what you were doing.

Whilst we can all have fleeting moments of happiness every day, there is something to be said about savouring those moments. In the same way you might use a small spoon to eat your favourite dessert so you can savour the taste you enjoy or when you replay that favourite movie scene which elicits loud belly laughs. Reliving or savouring your happy moments can bring more happiness into your life.

Develop an attitude of gratitude

We have all had moments where we have relived a negative emotion simply by thinking about it. Well, the same is true for thinking about happy moments. It’s a bit like gratitude – the more you pay attention to the things that you are grateful for in your life, the more likely you are to develop an attitude of gratitude. If you pay more attention to the things that make you happy, you might just be surprised at how much more happiness you experience in your life overall.  

To help you get started, write down five things that make you happy.

tabs.title: Good Thinking resources
tabs.content:
• My Possible Self – the Mood Tracker in this free app helps you to monitor how you feel every day and highlight activities, places and people that influence your mood so you can focus on the things that make you feel great and do less of the things that don’t
  • Be Mindful - this online Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy course teaches you practises to help you to maintain and enhance your general wellbeing for a happier and healthier life. The course is available for free to Londoners through Good Thinking
  • MyCognition PRO - this app helps you to improve your cognitive fitness, mental wellbeing and resilience to stress.The app is available for free to Londoners through Good Thinking
  • Five ways to good mental wellbeing – a guide containing some simple steps to boost your wellbeing (it’s also available for various faith communities)
  • Mindfulness workbook - these information sheets cover the benefits of mindfulness and provide guidance on how to become more mindful
  • Self-compassion workbook - a workbook to help to to introduce self-compassionate thinking and behaviours into your life
  • Mental health and wellbeing support for students - check out Good Thinking’s range of advice and support to help you to stay mentally health at college and university

tabs.title: Other mental wellbeing resources for black students
tabs.content:
• Black Minds Matter UK - charity organisation connecting black individuals and families with free mental health services
  • Black River Counselling – culturally specific short-term counselling for black people by black counsellors and psychotherapists in Lambeth and Southwark
  • Croydon BME Forum - provides mental health support to Croydon’s black and minority ethnic communities
  • NHS Talking Therapies - free NHS psychological therapies to support people with common mental health problems like anxiety and depression
  • The Empowerment Group (teg) - heavily subsidised online 1:1 culturally appropriate therapy for people of Black African and Caribbean heritage (please note that this is not a free service)
  • The Black, African and Asian Therapy Network - the largest community of Counsellors and Psychotherapists of Black, African, Asian and Caribbean Heritage in the UK
  • Mind - racism and mental health advice and support
  • YoungMinds - racism and mental health advice and support

contentSections.subtitle: This blog was written as part of the Office for Students' Black Students Mental Health Project at London South Bank University. Check out the full range of wellbeing resources available on the Good Thinking website.
contentSections.title: Mental wellbeing resources created by and for black students
